entry.title: Inapproximability of Combinatorial Optimization Problems
entry.summary: We survey results on the hardness of approximating combinatorial optimization problems.

entry.title: Exploring k-Colorability
entry.summary: An introductory paper to the graph k-colorability problem.

entry.title: Relativized Propositional Calculus
entry.summary: Proof systems for the Relativized Propositional Calculus are defined and compared.

entry.title: Phase Transitions and all that
entry.summary: The paper (as posted originally) contains several errors. It has been subsequently split into two papers, the corrected (and accepted for publication) versions appear in the archive as papers cs.CC/0503082 and cs.DM/0503083.

entry.title: Gales and supergales are equivalent for defining constructive Hausdorff dimension
entry.summary: We show that for a wide range of probability measures, constructive gales are interchangable with constructive supergales for defining constructive Hausdorff dimension, thus generalizing a previous independent result of Hitchcock (cs.CC/0208043) and partially answering an open question of Lutz (cs.CC/0203017).

entry.title: Separating the complexity classes NL and NP
entry.summary: Withdrawn since -order- was overlooked. First order reductions without order are much too weak to separate.

entry.title: P-Immune Sets with Holes Lack Self-Reducibility Properties
entry.summary: No P-immune set having exponential gaps is positive-Turing self-reducible.

entry.title: How long is a Proof? - A short note
entry.summary: Withdrawn. Silly notion and out of context.

entry.title: Solution Bounds for a Hypothetical Polynomial Time Aproximation Algorithm for the TSP
entry.summary: Bounds for the optimal tour length for a hypothetical TSP algorithm are derived.

entry.title: Solution of the Linear Ordering Problem (NP=P)
entry.summary: A polynomial algorithm is obtained for the NP-complete linear ordering problem.

entry.title: Defying Dimensions Mod 6
entry.summary: We show that a certain representation of the matrix-product can be computed with $n^{o(1)}$ multiplications. We also show, that siumilar representations of matrices can be compressed enormously.

entry.title: Alchemistry of the P versus NP question
entry.summary: Are P and NP provably inseparable ? Take a look at some unorthodox, guilty mentioned folklore and related unpublished results.

entry.title: P=NP
entry.summary: We claim to resolve the P=?NP problem via a formal argument for P=NP.

entry.title: On Polynomial Time Computable Numbers
entry.summary: It will be shown that the polynomial time computable numbers form a field, and especially an algebraically closed field.

entry.title: Polynomial time algorithm for 3-SAT. Examples of use
entry.summary: The algorithm checks the propositional formulas for patterns of unsatisfiability.

entry.title: Reducing SAT to 2-SAT
entry.summary: Description of a polynomial time reduction of SAT to 2-SAT of polynomial size.

entry.title: On the Double Coset Membership Problem for Permutation Groups
entry.summary: We show that the Double Coset Membership problem for permutation groups possesses perfect zero-knowledge proofs.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Algebraic structures and their applications, pp. 351--363 (2002)

entry.title: Ogden's Lemma for Regular Tree Languages
entry.summary: We motivate and prove a strong pumping lemma for regular tree languages. The new lemma can be seen as the natural correspondent of Ogden's lemma for context-free string languages.

entry.title: Can Random Coin Flips Speed Up a Computer?
entry.summary: This expository essay introduces randomness and computation to a lay audience.

entry.title: NP=PSPACE
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn by the author due to a misunderstanding about 3QBF.

entry.title: Unary Subset-Sum is in Logspace
entry.summary: We present a simple Logspace algorithm that solves the Unary Subset-Sum problem.

entry.title: A zero-one SUBEXP-dimension law for BPP
entry.summary: We show that BPP has either SUBEXP-dimension zero (randomness is easy) or BPP=EXP (randomness is intractable).
entry.arxiv:comment: to be published in information processing letters

entry.title: The 3-satisfiability problem
entry.summary: We present a deterministic polynomial-time algorithm that solves the 3-satisfiability problem.
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper is withdrawn by the author because a revision has been developed

entry.title: Zen Puzzle Garden is NP-complete
entry.summary: Zen Puzzle Garden (ZPG) is a one-player puzzle game. In this paper, we prove that deciding the solvability of ZPG is NP-complete.

entry.title: New separation between $s(f)$ and $bs(f)$
entry.summary: In this note we give a new separation between sensitivity and block sensitivity of Boolean functions: $bs(f)=(2/3)s(f)^2-(1/3)s(f)$.

entry.title: A Note on the Balanced ST-Connectivity
entry.summary: We prove that every YES instance of Balanced ST-Connectivity has a balanced path of polynomial length.

entry.title: Analysis of Boolean Functions
entry.summary: Scribe notes from the 2012 Barbados Workshop on Computational Complexity. A series of lectures on Analysis of Boolean Functions by Ryan O'Donnell, with a guest lecture by Per Austrin.

entry.title: Challenges in computational lower bounds
entry.summary: We draw two incomplete, biased maps of challenges in computational complexity lower bounds.

entry.title: Candy Crush is NP-hard
entry.summary: We prove that playing Candy Crush to achieve a given score in a fixed number of swaps is NP-hard.

entry.title: TrackMania is NP-complete
entry.summary: We prove that completing an untimed, unbounded track in TrackMania Nations Forever is NP-complete by using a reduction from 3-SAT and showing that a solution can be checked in polynomial time.

entry.title: An NL-Complete Puzzle
entry.summary: We investigate the complexity of a puzzle that turns out to be NL-complete.

entry.title: The Complexity of Some Combinatorial Puzzles
entry.summary: We show that the decision versions of the puzzles Knossos and The Hour-Glass are complete for NP.

entry.title: A Note on Graphs with 2 Bends
entry.summary: We show NP-completeness for the recognition problem of 2-line-bend graphs.

entry.title: SAT as a game
entry.summary: We propose a funny representation of SAT. While the primary interest is to present propositional satisfiability in a playful way for pedagogical purposes, it could also inspire new search heuristics.

entry.title: Lower bounds for sensitivity of graph properties
entry.summary: We prove that the sensitivity of any non-trivial graph property on $n$ vertices is at least $\lfloor \frac{1}{2}n \rfloor$ , provided $n$ is sufficiently large.

entry.title: A Note on Pointwise Dimensions
entry.summary: This short note describes a connection between algorithmic dimensions of individual points and classical pointwise dimensions of measures.

entry.title: Complexity of Domination in Triangulated Plane Graphs
entry.summary: We prove that for a triangulated plane graph it is NP-complete to determine its domination number and its power domination number.

entry.title: 2-CLUB is NP-hard for distance to 2-club cluster graphs
entry.summary: We show that 2-CLUB is NP-hard for distance to 2-club cluster graphs.

entry.title: LIKE Patterns and Complexity
entry.summary: We investigate the expressive power and complexity questions for the LIKE operator in SQL.

entry.title: A Reply to "On Salum's Algorithm for X3SAT"
entry.summary: This paper is a reply to "On Salum's Algorithm for X3SAT" (arXiv:2104.02886)

entry.title: A quantum algorithm for solving the 3-SAT problem
entry.summary: The method in this paper is wrong.

entry.title: A polynomial time approximation schema for maximum k-vertex cover in bipartite graphs
entry.summary: The paper presents a polynomial time approximation schema for the edge-weighted version of maximum k-vertex cover problem in bipartite graphs.

entry.title: A Simpler NP-Hardness Proof for Familial Graph Compression
entry.summary: This document presents a simpler proof showcasing the NP-hardness of Familial Graph Compression.

entry.title: How do humans succeed in tasks like proving Fermat's Theorem or predicting the Higgs boson?
entry.summary: I discuss issues of inverting feasibly computable functions, optimal discovery algorithms, and the constant overheads in their performance.

entry.title: On the Existence of Anomalies
entry.summary: The Independence Postulate (IP) is a finitary Church-Turing Thesis, saying mathematical sequences are independent from physical ones. IP implies the existence of anomalies.

entry.title: A Tight Lower Bound for Compact Set Packing
entry.summary: This note is devoted to show a simple proof of a tight lower bound of the parameterized compact set packing problem, based on ETH.

entry.title: Inapproximability of sufficient reasons for decision trees
entry.summary: In this note, we establish the hardness of approximation of the problem of computing the minimal size of a $\delta$-sufficient reason for decision trees.

entry.title: The discrepancy of greater-than
entry.summary: The discrepancy of the $n \times n$ greater-than matrix is shown to be $\frac{\pi}{2 \ln n}$ up to lower order terms.

entry.title: Proofs of Equalities NP = coNP = PSPACE: Simplification
entry.summary: In this paper we present simplified proofs of our results NP = coNP = PSPACE.
entry.arxiv:comment: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with arXiv:2012.04437

entry.title: Nested satisfiability
entry.summary: A special case of the satisfiability problem, in which the clauses have a hierarchical structure, is shown to be solvable in linear time, assuming that the clauses have been represented in a convenient way.

entry.title: Textbook examples of recursion
entry.summary: We discuss properties of recursive schemas related to McCarthy's ``91 function'' and to Takeuchi's triple recursion. Several theorems are proposed as interesting candidates for machine verification, and some intriguing open questions are raised.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Artificial intelligence and mathematical theory of computation

entry.title: A Generalized Quantifier Concept in Computational Complexity Theory
entry.summary: A notion of generalized quantifier in computational complexity theory is explored and used to give a unified treatment of leaf language definability, oracle separations, type 2 operators, and circuits with monoidal gates. Relations to Lindstroem quantifiers are pointed out.

entry.title: Recursively Undecidable Properties of NP
entry.summary: We show that there cannot be any algorithm that for a given nondeterministic polynomial-time Turing machine determinates whether or not the language recognized by this machine belongs to P

entry.title: Gales Suffice for Constructive Dimension
entry.summary: Supergales, generalizations of supermartingales, have been used by Lutz (2002) to define the constructive dimensions of individual binary sequences. Here it is shown that gales, the corresponding generalizations of martingales, can be equivalently used to define constructive dimension.

entry.title: Hard satisfiable formulas for DPLL-type algorithms
entry.summary: We address lower bounds on the time complexity of algorithms solving the propositional satisfiability problem. Namely, we consider two DPLL-type algorithms, enhanced with the unit clause and pure literal heuristics. Exponential lower bounds for solving satisfiability on provably satisfiable formulas are proven.

entry.title: Minimal DFAs for Testing Divisibility
entry.summary: We present and prove a theorem answering the question "how many states does a minimal deterministic finite automaton (DFA) that recognizes the set of base-b numbers divisible by k have?"
entry.arxiv:comment: LaTeX, 7 pages (corrected typo in new version)

entry.title: Note on Counting Eulerian Circuits
entry.summary: We show that the problem of counting the number of Eulerian circuits in an undirected graph is complete for the class #P.

entry.title: Hardware-Oriented Group Solutions for Hard Problems
entry.summary: Group and individual solutions are considered for hard problems such as satisfiability problem. Time-space trade-off in a structured active memory provides means to achieve lower time complexity for solutions of these problems.

entry.title: On computing fixed points for generalized sandpiles
entry.summary: We prove fixed points results for sandpiles starting with arbitrary initial conditions. We give an effective algorithm for computing such fixed points, and we refine it in the particular case of SPM.

entry.title: The role of Quantum Interference in Quantum Computing
entry.summary: Quantum interference is proposed as a tool to augment Quantum Computation.

entry.title: Entropy, Convex Optimization, and Competitive Quantum Interactions
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn by the author due to errors.

entry.title: Restricted Complexity, General Complexity
entry.summary: Why has the problematic of complexity appeared so late? And why would it be justified?
entry.arxiv:comment: 25 pages. Presented at the Colloquium "Intelligence de la complexit'e : 'epist'emologie et pragmatique", Cerisy-La-Salle, France, June 26th, 2005. Translated from French by Carlos Gershenson

entry.title: On "P = NP: Linear Programming Formulation of the Traveling Salesman Problem": A reply to Hofman's Claim of a "Counter-Example"
entry.summary: We show that Hofman's claim of a "counter-example" to Diaby's LP formulation of the TSP is invalid.

entry.title: A Counterexample to a Proposed Proof of P=NP by S. Gubin
entry.summary: In a recent paper by S. Gubin [cs/0701023v1], a polynomial-time solution to the 3SAT problem was presented as proof that P=NP. The proposed algorithm cannot be made to work, which I shall demonstrate.

entry.title: On the Complexity of a Derivative Chess Problem
entry.summary: We introduce QUEENS, a derivative chess problem based on the classical n-queens problem. We prove that QUEENS is NP-complete, with respect to polynomial-time reductions.

entry.title: Tree Automata and Essential Input Variables
entry.summary: We introduce and study the essential inputs (variables) for terms (trees) and tree automata.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages, 2 figures, 60th Workshop on General Algebra, June 22-25, 2000, TU Dresden
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: J. Contributions to General Algebra, v.13, Verlag Johannes Heyn, Klagenfurt, 2001, 309-319 p

entry.title: Fast Exact Method for Solving the Travelling Salesman Problem
entry.summary: This paper describes TSP exact solution of polynomial complexity. It is considered properties of proposed method. Effectiveness of proposed solution is illustrated by outcomes of computer modeling.

entry.title: Graph Isomorphism is PSPACE-complete
entry.summary: Combining the the results of A.R. Meyer and L.J. Stockmeyer "The Equivalence Problem for Regular Expressions with Squaring Requires Exponential Space", and K.S. Booth "Isomorphism testing for graphs, semigroups, and finite automata are polynomiamlly equivalent problems" shows that graph isomorphism is PSPACE-complete.

entry.title: P-matrix recognition is co-NP-complete
entry.summary: This is a summary of the proof by G.E. Coxson that P-matrix recognition is co-NP-complete. The result follows by a reduction from the MAX CUT problem using results of S. Poljak and J. Rohn.

entry.title: On the graph isomorphism problem
entry.summary: We relate the graph isomorphism problem to the solvability of certain systems of linear equations with nonnegative variables. This version replaces the two previous versions of this paper.

entry.title: Zero-Knowledge Proofs of the Conjugacy for Permutation Groups
entry.summary: We design a perfect zero-knowledge proof system for recognition if two permutation groups are conjugate.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Bulletin of the Lviv University, Series in Mechanics and Mathematics. Vol. 61, pp. 195--205 (2003)

entry.title: Longest paths in Planar DAGs in Unambiguous Logspace
entry.summary: We show via two different algorithms that finding the length of the longest path in planar directed acyclic graph (DAG) is in unambiguous logspace UL, and also in the complement class co-UL. The result extends to toroidal DAGs as well.

entry.title: 3-connected Planar Graph Isomorphism is in Log-space
entry.summary: We show that the isomorphism of 3-connected planar graphs can be decided in deterministic log-space. This improves the previously known bound UL$\cap$coUL of Thierauf and Wagner.

entry.title: 1.25 Approximation Algorithm for the Steiner Tree Problem with Distances One and Two
entry.summary: We give a 1.25 approximation algorithm for the Steiner Tree Problem with distances one and two, improving on the best known bound for that problem.

entry.title: A Superpolynomial Lower Bound on the Size of Uniform Non-constant-depth Threshold Circuits for the Permanent
entry.summary: We show that the permanent cannot be computed by DLOGTIME-uniform threshold or arithmetic circuits of depth o(log log n) and polynomial size.

entry.title: On P vs. NP, Geometric Complexity Theory, Explicit Proofs and the Complexity Barrier
entry.summary: Geometric complexity theory (GCT) is an approach to the P vs. NP and related problems. This article gives its complexity theoretic overview without assuming any background in algebraic geometry or representation theory.

entry.title: Résolution du "partition problem" par une approche arithmétique
entry.summary: This article has been withdrawn
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn by the author due to a crucial error (in one of the quadratic forms introduced)

entry.title: Polynomially Correlated Knapsack is NP-complete
entry.summary: 0-1 Knapsack is a fundamental NP-complete problem. In this article we prove that it remains NP-complete even when the weights of the objects in the packing constraints and their values in the objective function satisfy specific stringent conditions: the values are integral powers of the weights of the objects.

entry.title: New Learning and Testing Problems for Read-Once Functions
entry.summary: In the paper, we consider several types of queries for classical and new problems of learning and testing read-once functions. In several cases, the border between polynomial and exponential complexities is obtained.

entry.title: Partitionability to two trees is NP-complete
entry.summary: We show that P2T - the problem of deciding whether the edge set of a simple graph can be partitioned into two trees or not - is NP-complete.

entry.title: Quantum Complexity: restrictions on algorithms and architectures
entry.summary: A dissertation submitted to the University of Bristol in accordance with the requirements of the degree of Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) in the Faculty of Engineering, Department of Computer Science, July 2009.

entry.title: On a new complete invariant of acyclic graphs
entry.summary: A new complete invariant for acyclic graphs is presented
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn by the author due to update

entry.title: Motion planning with pull moves
entry.summary: It is well known that Sokoban is PSPACE-complete (Culberson 1998) and several of its variants are NP-hard (Demaine et al. 2003). In this paper we prove the NP-hardness of some variants of Sokoban where the warehouse keeper can only pull boxes.

entry.title: Quantum function computation using sublogarithmic space (abstract & poster)
entry.summary: We prove that quantum Turing machines are strictly superior to probabilistic Turing machines in function computation for any space bound $ o(\log(n)) $.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages, poster presented at the 13th Workshop on Quantum Information Processing (QIP2010)

entry.title: Variations on the Sensitivity Conjecture
entry.summary: We present a selection of known as well as new variants of the Sensitivity Conjecture and point out some weaker versions that are also open.

entry.title: $k$-Independent Gaussians Fool Polynomial Threshold Functions
entry.summary: We show that any $O_d(\epsilon^{-4d 7^d})$-independent family of Gaussians $\epsilon$-fools any degree-$d$ polynomial threshold function.

entry.title: NP-completeness Proof: RBCDN Reduction Problem
entry.summary: Computational complexity of the design problem for a network with a target value of Region-Based Component Decomposition Number (RBCDN) has been proven to be NP-complete.

entry.title: New Definition for Fuzzy Constraint Satisfaction Problem and its Applications
entry.summary: This article has been withdrawn.

entry.title: Derandomizing HSSW Algorithm for 3-SAT
entry.summary: We present a (full) derandomization of HSSW algorithm for 3-SAT, proposed by Hofmeister, Sch\"oning, Schuler, and Watanabe in [STACS'02]. Thereby, we obtain an O(1.3303^n)-time deterministic algorithm for 3-SAT, which is currently fastest.

entry.title: BPP is in NP and coNP
entry.summary: We show that the class BPP is in NP and coNP. This paper has been withdrawn by the author because B and B' are probabilistic and nonequalities 10 cannot be checked in polynomial time.

entry.title: A Small PRG for Polynomial Threshold Functions of Gaussians
entry.summary: We develop a pseudo-random generator to fool degree-$d$ polynomial threshold functions with respect to the Gaussian distribution. For $c>0$ any constant, we construct a pseudo-random generator that fools such functions to within $\epsilon$ and has seed length $\log(n) 2^{O(d)} \epsilon^{-4-c}$.

entry.title: Algorithmic complexity of pair cleaning method for k-satisfiability problem. (draft version)
entry.summary: The k-satisfiability problem is a well-known task in computational complexity theory. In this paper approach for it's solving is introduced.

entry.title: Tron, a combinatorial Game on abstract Graphs
entry.summary: We study the combinatorial two-player game Tron. We answer the extremal question on general graphs and also consider smaller graph classes. Bodlaender and Kloks conjectured in [2] PSPACE- completeness. We proof this conjecture.

entry.title: A Casual Tour Around a Circuit Complexity Bound
entry.summary: I will discuss the recent proof that the complexity class NEXP (nondeterministic exponential time) lacks nonuniform ACC circuits of polynomial size. The proof will be described from the perspective of someone trying to discover it.
entry.arxiv:comment: 21 pages, 2 figures. An earlier version appeared in SIGACT News, September 2011

entry.title: Scrabble is PSPACE-Complete
entry.summary: In this paper we study the computational complexity of the game of Scrabble. We prove the PSPACE-completeness of a derandomized model of the game, answering an open question of Erik Demaine and Robert Hearn.

entry.title: How to solve kSAT in polynomial time
entry.summary: With using of multi-nary logic analytic formulas proposition that "kSAT is in P and could be solved in $O(n^{3.5})$" was proved

entry.title: Clique in 3-track interval graphs is APX-hard
entry.summary: Butman, Hermelin, Lewenstein, and Rawitz proved that Clique in t-interval graphs is NP-hard for t >= 3. We strengthen this result to show that Clique in 3-track interval graphs is APX-hard.

entry.title: A new point of NP-hardness for 2-to-1 Label Cover
entry.summary: We show that given a satisfiable instance of the 2-to-1 Label Cover problem, it is NP-hard to find a $(23/24 + \eps)$-satisfying assignment.

entry.title: P versus UP
entry.summary: Admin note: withdrawn by arXiv admin because of the use of a pseudonym, in violation of arXiv policy.
entry.arxiv:comment: Administratively withdrawn due to policy violations

entry.title: On the Complexity of Minimum Labeling Alignment of Two Genomes
entry.summary: In this note we investigate the complexity of the Minimum Label Alignment problem and we show that such a problem is APX-hard.

entry.title: Decomposition of Kolmogorov Complexity And Link To Geometry
entry.summary: A link between Kolmogorov Complexity and geometry is uncovered. A similar concept of projection and vector decomposition is described for Kolmogorov Complexity. By using a simple approximation to the Kolmogorov Complexity, coded in Mathematica, the derived formulas are tested and used to study the geometry of Light Cone.

entry.title: A sufficient condition for first order non-definability of arrowing problems
entry.summary: We here present a sufficient condition for general arrowing problems to be non definable in first order logic, based in well known tools of finite model theory e.g. Hanf's Theorem and known concepts in finite combinatorics, like senders and determiners.

entry.title: A Note on Kolmogorov-Uspensky Machines
entry.summary: Solving an open problem stated by Shvachko, it is shown that a language which is not real-time recognizable by some variants of pointer machines can be accepted by a Kolmogorov-Uspensky machine in real-time.

entry.title: Improved Hardness of Approximating Chromatic Number
entry.summary: We prove that for sufficiently large K, it is NP-hard to color K-colorable graphs with less than 2^{K^{1/3}} colors. This improves the previous result of K versus K^{O(log K)} in Khot [14].

entry.title: Short lists with short programs in short time - a short proof
entry.summary: Bauwens, Mahklin, Vereshchagin and Zimand [ECCC TR13-007] and Teutsch [arxiv:1212.6104] have shown that given a string x it is possible to construct in polynomial time a list containing a short description of it. We simplify their technique and present a shorter proof of this result.

entry.title: Algebraic Complexity Classes
entry.summary: This survey describes, at an introductory level, the algebraic complexity framework originally proposed by Leslie Valiant in 1979, and some of the insights that have been obtained more recently.
entry.arxiv:comment: Corrected some typos, added some references

entry.title: Hard Asymptotic Sets for One-Dimensional Cellular Automata
entry.summary: We prove that the (language of the) asymptotic set (and the nonwandering set) of a one-dimensional cellular automaton can be $\SIGMA^1_1$-hard. We do not go into much detail, since the constructions are relatively standard.

entry.title: Fixed Parameter Inapproximability for Clique and SetCover in Time Super-exponential in OPT
entry.summary: In this paper, we consider proving inapproximability in terms of OPT and thus we base the foundations of fixed parameter inapproximability.

entry.title: High Dimensional Expanders and Property Testing
entry.summary: We show that the high dimensional expansion property as defined by Gromov, Linial and Meshulam, for simplicial complexes is a form of testability. Namely, a simplicial complex is a high dimensional expander iff a suitable property is testable. Using this connection, we derive several testability results.

entry.title: A Polylogarithmic PRG for Degree $2$ Threshold Functions in the Gaussian Setting
entry.summary: We devise a new pseudorandom generator against degree 2 polynomial threshold functions in the Gaussian setting. We manage to achieve $\epsilon$ error with seed length polylogarithmic in $\epsilon$ and the dimension, and exponential improvement over previous constructions.

entry.title: Deciding the On-line Chromatic Number of a Graph with Pre-Coloring is PSPACE-Complete
entry.summary: The problem of determining if the on-line chromatic number of a graph is less than or equal to k, given a pre-coloring, is shown to be PSPACE-complete.

entry.title: On relative OR-complexity of Boolean matrices and their complements
entry.summary: We construct explicit Boolean square matrices whose rectifier complexity (OR-complexity) differs significantly from the complexity of their complement matrices.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, published in Russian in Proc. 17-th Int. Conf. on Problems of Theoretical Cybernetics (Kazan, 16-20 June 2014), 262-264

entry.title: Faster FPT Algorithm for Graph Isomorphism Parameterized by Eigenvalue Multiplicity
entry.summary: We give a $O^*(k^{O(k)})$ time isomorphism testing algorithm for graphs of eigenvalue multiplicity bounded by $k$ which improves on the previous best running time bound of $O^*(2^{O(k^2/\log k)})$.

entry.title: About accuracy of the solution of NP-complete tasks
entry.summary: On example of tasks of class NP the questions concerning accuracy of work of already existing and possible in the future algorithms for the solution of tasks on discrete structures are considered.

entry.title: Computing an Evolutionary Ordering is Hard
entry.summary: We prove that computing an evolutionary ordering of a family of sets, i.e. an ordering where each set intersects with --but is not included in-- the union earlier sets, is NP-hard.

entry.title: NP-hardness of hypercube 2-segmentation
entry.summary: The hypercube 2-segmentation problem is a certain biclustering problem that was previously claimed to be NP-hard, but for which there does not appear to be a publicly available proof of NP-hardness. This manuscript provides such a proof.

entry.title: On families of anticommuting matrices
entry.summary: Let $e_{1},\dots, e_{k}$ be complex $n\times n$ matrices such that $e_{i}e_{j}=-e_{j}e_{i}$ whenever $i\not=j$. We conjecture that $\hbox{rk}(e_{1}^{2})+\hbox{rk}(e_{2}^{2})+\cdots+\hbox{rk}(e_{k}^{2})\leq O(n\log n)$, and prove some results in this direction.

entry.title: Efficient Computation by Three Counter Machines
entry.summary: We show that multiplication can be done in polynomial time on a three counter machine that receives its input as the contents of two counters. The technique is generalized to functions of two variables computable by deterministic Turing machines in linear space.

entry.title: Lower Bound for General Circuits Computing Clique Function
entry.summary: We prove an exponential lower bound for general circuits computing the clique function and hereby confirm that NP != P.
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn by the author due to a crucial error in Section 3

entry.title: On a logical model of combinatorial problems
entry.summary: The paper proposes a logical model of combinatorial problems, also it gives an example of a problem of the class NP that can not be solved in polynomial time on the dimension of the problem.

entry.title: An Extended Coding Theorem with Application to Quantum Complexities
entry.summary: This paper introduces a new inequality in algorithmic information theory that can be seen as an extended coding theorem. This inequality has applications in new bounds between quantum complexity measures.

entry.title: Decentralization of a Machine: Some Definitions
entry.summary: We define some notions of the decentralization of a deterministic input-output machine. This opens the possibility for introducing game-theoretic elements -- such as strategic players -- inside the machine, as part of its design.

entry.title: Spectral and Modular Analysis of #P Problems
entry.summary: We present various analytic and number theoretic results concerning the #SAT problem as reflected when reduced into a #PART problem. As an application we propose a heuristic to probabilistically estimate the solution of #SAT problems.

entry.title: PSPACE-Complete Two-Color Placement Games
entry.summary: We show that three placement games, Col, NoGo, and Fjords, are PSPACE-complete on planar graphs. The hardness of Col and Fjords is shown via a reduction from Bounded 2-Player Constraint Logic and NoGo is shown to be hard directly from Col.

entry.title: A handle is enough for a hard game of Pull
entry.summary: We are going to show that some variants of a puzzle called Pull in which the boxes have handles (i.e. we can only pull the boxes in certain directions) are NP-hard

entry.title: Generic case completeness
entry.summary: In this note we introduce a notion of a generically (strongly generically) NP-complete problem and show that the randomized bounded version of the halting problem is strongly generically NP-complete.

entry.title: A $2n^2-log(n)-1$ lower bound for the border rank of matrix multiplication
entry.summary: Let M_n denote the matrix multiplication tensor for nxn matrices. We use the border substitution method combined with Koszul flattenings to prove the border rank lower bound of 2n^2-log(n)-1 for M_n.

entry.title: #P- and $\oplus$P- completeness of counting roots of a sparse polynomial
entry.summary: We improve and simplify the result of the part 4 of "Counting curves and their projections" (Joachim von zur Gathen, Marek Karpinski, Igor Shparlinski) by showing that counting roots of a sparse polynomial over $\mathbb{F}_{2^n}$ is #P- and $\oplus$P-complete under deterministic reductions.

entry.title: Consensus Patterns parameterized by input string length is W[1]-hard
entry.summary: We consider the Consensus Patterns problem, where, given a set of input strings, one is asked to extract a long-enough pattern which appears (with some errors) in all strings. We prove that this problem is W[1]-hard when parameterized by the maximum length of input strings.

entry.title: The Unbounded-Error Communication Complexity of symmetric XOR functions
entry.summary: Settling a conjecture of Shi and Zhang, we determine the unbounded-error communication complexity of the symmetric XOR functions up to a poly-logarithmic factor. Our proof is by a simple reduction to an earlier result of Sherstov.

entry.title: Boolean quadric polytopes are faces of linear ordering polytopes
entry.summary: Let $BQP(n)$ be a boolean quadric polytope, $LOP(m)$ be a linear ordering polytope. It is shown that $BQP(n)$ is linearly isomorphic to a face of $LOP(2n)$.

entry.title: A non-commutative algorithm for multiplying 5x5 matrices using 99 multiplications
entry.summary: We present a non-commutative algorithm for multiplying 5x5 matrices using 99 multiplications. This algorithm is a minor modification of Makarov's algorithm which exhibit the previous best known bound with 100 multiplications.

entry.title: Refuting Feder, Kinne and Rafiey
entry.summary: I give an example showing that the recent claimed solution by Feder, Kinne and Rafiey to the CSP Dichotomy Conjecture is not correct.
entry.arxiv:comment: This note is in response to arXiv:1701.02409 versions (v1)-(v3) by T. Feder, J. Kinne, and A. Rafiey

entry.title: Nondeterministic Communication Complexity with Help and Graph Functions
entry.summary: We define nondeterministic communication complexity in the model of communication complexity with help of Babai, Hayes and Kimmel. We use it to prove logarithmic lower bounds on the NOF communication complexity of explicit graph functions, which are complementary to the bounds proved by Beame, David, Pitassi and Woelfel.

entry.title: Non-Interlaced SAT is in P
entry.summary: We investigate the NP-Complete problem SAT and the geometry of its instances. For a particular type that we call {\it non-interlaced formulas}, we propose a polynomial time algorithm for their resolution using graphs and matrices.

entry.title: The complexity of matrix multiplication: developments since 2014. Extended abstract of 2018 Oberwolfach Complexity meeting plenary lecture
entry.summary: This is an overview of recent developments regarding the complexity of matrix multiplication, with an emphasis on the uses of algebraic geometry and representation theory in complexity theory.

entry.title: A note on the complexity of integer programming games
entry.summary: In this brief note, we prove that the existence of Nash equilibria on integer programming games is $\Sigma^p_2$-complete.

entry.title: Bare quantum simultaneity versus classical interactivity in communication complexity
entry.summary: A relational bipartite communication problem is presented that has an efficient quantum simultaneous-messages protocol, but no efficient classical two-way protocol.

entry.title: Three-dimensional matching is NP-Hard
entry.summary: The standard proof of NP-Hardness of 3DM provides a power-$4$ reduction of 3SAT to 3DM. In this note, we provide a linear-time reduction. Under the exponential time hypothesis, this reduction improves the runtime lower bound from $2^{o(\sqrt[4]{m})}$ (under the standard reduction) to $2^{o(m)}$.

entry.title: Lecture Note on LCSSX's Lower Bounds for Non-Adaptive Distribution-free Property Testing
entry.summary: In this lecture note we give Liu-Chen-Servedio-Sheng-Xie's (LCSSX) lower bound for property testing in the non-adaptive distribution-free.
entry.arxiv:comment: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with arXiv:1802.04859 by other authors

entry.title: A stochastic calculus approach to the oracle separation of BQP and PH
entry.summary: After presentations of Raz and Tal's oracle separation of BQP and PH result, several people (e.g. Ryan O'Donnell, James Lee, Avishay Tal) suggested that the proof may be simplified by stochastic calculus. In this short note, we describe such a simplification.

entry.title: An in-place truncated Fourier transform
entry.summary: We show that simple modifications to van der Hoeven's forward and inverse truncated Fourier transforms allow the algorithms to be performed in-place, and with only a linear overhead in complexity.

entry.title: Polytime reductions of AF-algebraic problems
entry.summary: We assess the computational complexity of several decision problems concerning (Murray-von Neumann) equivalence classes of projections of AF-algebras whose Elliott classifier is lattice-ordered. We construct polytime reductions among many of these problems.

entry.title: Analyzing XOR-Forrelation through stochastic calculus
entry.summary: In this note we present a simplified analysis of the quantum and classical complexity of the $k$-XOR Forrelation problem (introduced in the paper of Girish, Raz and Zhan) by a stochastic interpretation of the Forrelation distribution.

entry.title: The inverse of Ackermann function is computable in linear time
entry.summary: We propose a detailed proof of the fact that the inverse of Ackermann function is computable in linear time.

entry.title: On the complexity of SAT
entry.summary: In this paper, we prove that no deterministic algorithm can solve SAT in polynomial time in the number of boolean variables.

entry.title: A Survey on Parameterized Inapproximability: $k$-Clique, $k$-SetCover, and More
entry.summary: In the past a few years, many interesting inapproximability results have been obtained from the parameterized perspective. This article surveys some of such results, with a focus on $k$-Clique, $k$-SetCover, and other related problems.

entry.title: No Efficient Disjunction or Conjunction of Switch-Lists
entry.summary: It is shown that disjunction of two switch-lists can blow up the representation size exponentially. Since switch-lists can be negated without any increase in size, this shows that conjunction of switch-lists also leads to an exponential blow-up in general.

entry.title: Does P=NP?
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn Abstract: This paper has been withdrawn by the author due to the publication.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Karlen Gharibyan, Does P=NP?, in Proceedings of the first international Arm Tech Congress 2007

entry.title: Common Permutation Problem
entry.summary: In this paper we show that the following problem is NP-complete: Given an alphabet $\Sigma$ and two strings over $\Sigma$, the question is whether there exists a permutation of $\Sigma$ which is a subsequence of both of the given strings.

entry.title: Errors in Improved Polynomial Algorithm For 3 Sat Proposed By Narendra Chaudhari
entry.summary: There are errors in the algorithm proposed by Narendra Chaudhari [2] purporting to solve the 3-sat problem in polynomial time. The present paper present instances for which the algorithm outputs erroneous results.

entry.title: A Pseudorandom Generator for Polynomial Threshold Functions of Gaussian with Subpolynomial Seed Length
entry.summary: We develop a pseudorandom generator that fools degree-$d$ polynomial threshold functions in $n$ variables with respect to the Gaussian distribution and has seed length $O_{c,d}(\log(n) \epsilon^{-c})$.

entry.title: Critique of Barbosa's "P != NP Proof"
entry.summary: We review Andr\'e Luiz Barbosa's paper "P != NP Proof," in which the classes P and NP are generalized and claimed to be proven separate. We highlight inherent ambiguities in Barbosa's definitions, and show that attempts to resolve this ambiguity lead to flaws in the proof of his main result.

entry.title: Near-Optimal Communication Lower Bounds for Approximate Nash Equilibria
entry.summary: We prove an $N^{2-o(1)}$ lower bound on the randomized communication complexity of finding an $\epsilon$-approximate Nash equilibrium (for constant $\epsilon>0$) in a two-player $N\times N$ game.

entry.title: The Packed Interval Covering Problem is NP-complete
entry.summary: We introduce a new decision problem, called Packed Interval Covering (PIC) and show that it is NP-complete.

entry.title: NP-complete variants of some classical graph problems
entry.summary: Some classical graph problems such as finding minimal spanning tree, shortest path or maximal flow can be done efficiently. We describe slight variations of such problems which are shown to be NP-complete. Our proofs use straightforward reduction from $3$-SAT.

entry.title: Does QRAT simulate IR-calc? QRAT simulation algorithm for $\forall$Exp+Res cannot be lifted to IR-calc
entry.summary: We show that the QRAT simulation algorithm of $\forall$Exp+Res from [B. Kiesl and M. Seidl, 2019] cannot be lifted to IR-calc.

entry.title: On the Kolmogorov Complexity of Binary Classifiers
entry.summary: We provide tight upper and lower bounds on the expected minimum Kolmogorov complexity of binary classifiers that are consistent with labeled samples. The expected size is not more than complexity of the target concept plus the conditional entropy of the labels given the sample.

entry.title: On The "Majority is Least Stable" Conjecture
entry.summary: We show that the "majority is least stable" conjecture is true for $n=1$ and $3$ and false for all odd $n\geq 5$.

entry.title: Parallel Repetition for the GHZ Game: Exponential Decay
entry.summary: We show that the value of the $n$-fold repeated GHZ game is at most $2^{-\Omega(n)}$, improving upon the polynomial bound established by Holmgren and Raz. Our result is established via a reduction to approximate subgroup type questions from additive combinatorics.

entry.title: Optimizing the half-gcd algorithm
entry.summary: In this paper, we propose a carefully optimized "half-gcd" algorithm for polynomials. We achieve a constant speed-up with respect to previous work for the asymptotic time complexity. We also discuss special optimizations that are possible when polynomial multiplication is done using radix two FFTs.

entry.title: On the Existence of Anomalies, The Reals Case
entry.summary: The Independence Postulate (IP) is a finitary Church-Turing Thesis, saying mathematical sequences are independent from physical ones. Modelling observations as infinite sequences of real numbers, IP implies the existence of anomalies.

entry.title: Regression and Algorithmic Information Theory
entry.summary: In this paper we prove a theorem about regression, in that the shortest description of a function consistent with a finite sample of data is less than the combined conditional Kolmogorov complexities over the data in the sample.

entry.title: A note on the complexity of addition
entry.summary: We show that the sum of a sequence of integers can be computed in linear time on a Turing machine. In particular, the most obvious algorithm for this problem, which appears to require quadratic time due to carry propagation, actually runs in linear time by amortized analysis.

entry.title: A Note on the Complexity of One-Sided Crossing Minimization of Trees
entry.summary: In 2011, Harrigan and Healy published a polynomial-time algorithm for one-sided crossing minimization for trees. We point out a counterexample to that algorithm, and show that one-sided crossing minimization is NP-hard for trees.

entry.title: The Randomness Deficiency Function and the Shift Operator
entry.summary: Almost surely, the difference between the randomness deficiencies of two infinite sequences will be unbounded with respect to repeated iterations of the shift operator.

entry.title: Enumeration Complexity: Incremental Time, Delay and Space
entry.summary: This habilitation thesis is intended to be a good introduction to enumeration, the problem of listing solutions. It focuses on the different ways of measuring complexity in enumeration, with a particular emphasis on my contributions to the field.

entry.title: Parallel Repetition of k-Player Projection Games
entry.summary: We study parallel repetition of k-player games where the constraints satisfy the projection property. We prove exponential decay in the value of a parallel repetition of projection games with value less than 1.

entry.title: What Juris Hartmanis taught me about Reductions
entry.summary: I was a student of Juris Hartmanis at Cornell in the late 1970's. He believed that there was great potential in studying restricted reductions. I describe here some of his influences on me and, in particular, how his insights concerning reductions helped me to prove that nondeterministic space is closed under complementation.

entry.title: L is different from NP
entry.summary: We prove that the class LOGSPACE (L, for short) is different from the class NP.

entry.title: Newman's theorem via Carathéodory
entry.summary: We give a streamlined short proof of Newman's theorem in communication complexity by applying the classical and the approximate Carath\'eodory's theorems.

entry.title: Battle Sheep is PSPACE-complete
entry.summary: Battle Sheep is a board game published by Blue Orange Games. With two players, it is a combinatorial game that uses normal play rules. We show that it is PSPACE-complete, even when each stack has only up to 3 tokens.

entry.title: New Applications of the Incompressibility Method: Part II
entry.summary: The incompressibility method is an elementary yet powerful proof technique. It has been used successfully in many areas. To further demonstrate its power and elegance we exhibit new simple proofs using the incompressibility method.

entry.title: New Applications of the Incompressibility Method: Part I
entry.summary: The incompressibility method is an elementary yet powerful proof technique. It has been used successfully in many areas. To further demonstrate its power and elegance we exhibit new simple proofs using the incompressibility method.
entry.arxiv:comment: 15 pages. To appear in The Computer Journal

entry.title: A Moment of Perfect Clarity II: Consequences of Sparse Sets Hard for NP with Respect to Weak Reductions
entry.summary: This paper discusses advances, due to the work of Cai, Naik, and Sivakumar and Glasser, in the complexity class collapses that follow if NP has sparse hard sets under reductions weaker than (full) truth-table reductions.

entry.title: On some optimization problems for star-free graphs
entry.summary: It is shown that in star-free graphs the maximum independent set problem, the minimum dominating set problem and the minimum independent dominating set problem are approximable up to constant factor by any maximal independent set.

entry.title: A comparison of Zeroes and Ones of a Boolean Polynomial
entry.summary: In this paper we consider the computational complexity of the following problem. Let $f$ be a Boolean polynomial. What value of $f$, 0 or 1, is taken more frequently? The problem is solved in polynomial time for polynomials of degrees 1,2. The next case of degree 3 appears to be PP-complete under polynomial reductions in the class of promise problems. The proof is based on techniques of quantum computation.

entry.title: Mathematical basis for polySAT implication operator
entry.summary: The mathematical basis motivating the "implication operator" of the polySAT algorithm and its function is examined. Such is not undertaken with onerous rigor of symbolic mathematics; a more intuitive visual appeal being employed to present some of the mathematical premises underlying function of the implication operator.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, 7 figures. Keywords: algorithms, complexity, computation theory, satisfiability, group theory, field theory, set theory

entry.title: Cellular automata and communication complexity
entry.summary: The model of cellular automata is fascinating because very simple local rules can generate complex global behaviors. The relationship between local and global function is subject of many studies. We tackle this question by using results on communication complexity theory and, as a by-product, we provide (yet another) classification of cellular automata.

entry.title: Near Quadratic Matrix Multiplication Modulo Composites
entry.summary: We show how one can use non-prime-power, composite moduli for computing representations of the product of two $n\times n$ matrices using only $n^{2+o(1)}$ multiplications.

entry.title: Some remarks on the survey decimation algorithm for K-satisfiability
entry.summary: In this note we study the convergence of the survey decimation algorithm. An analytic formula for the reduction of the complexity during the decimation is derived. The limit of the converge of the algorithm are estimated in the random case: interesting phenomena appear near the boundary of convergence.

entry.title: Individual Communication Complexity
entry.summary: We initiate the theory of communication complexity of individual inputs held by the agents, rather than worst-case or average-case. We consider total, partial, and partially correct protocols, one-way versus two-way, with and without help bits. The results are expressed in trems of Kolmogorov complexity.

entry.title: How NP got a new definition: a survey of probabilistically checkable proofs
entry.summary:
We survey a collective achievement of a group of researchers: the PCP Theorems. They give new definitions of the class 
p, and imply that computing approximate solutions to many 
p-hard problems is itself 
p-hard. Techniques developed to prove them have had many other consequences.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Proceedings of the ICM, Beijing 2002, vol. 3, 637--648

entry.title: Constraint Optimization and Statistical Mechanics
entry.summary: In these lectures I will present an introduction to the results that have been recently obtained in constraint optimization of random problems using statistical mechanics techniques. After presenting the general results, in order to simplify the presentation I will describe in details only the problems related to the coloring of a random graph.
entry.arxiv:comment: 22 pages, 1 figure Lectures given at the Varenna summer school

entry.title: A note on dimensions of polynomial size circuits
entry.summary: In this paper, we use resource-bounded dimension theory to investigate polynomial size circuits. We show that for every $i\geq 0$, $\Ppoly$ has $i$th order scaled $\pthree$-strong dimension 0. We also show that $\Ppoly^\io$ has $\pthree$-dimension 1/2, $\pthree$-strong dimension 1. Our results improve previous measure results of Lutz (1992) and dimension results of Hitchcock and Vinodchandran (2004).

entry.title: All Superlinear Inverse Schemes are coNP-Hard
entry.summary: How hard is it to invert NP-problems? We show that all superlinearly certified inverses of NP problems are coNP-hard. To do so, we develop a novel proof technique that builds diagonalizations against certificates directly into a circuit.

entry.title: The state complexity of L^2 and L^k
entry.summary: We show that if M is a DFA with n states over an arbitrary alphabet and L = L(M), then the worst-case state complexity of L^2 is n*2^n - 2^{n-1}. If, however, M is a DFA over a unary alphabet, then the worst-case state complexity of L^k is kn-k+1 for all k >= 2.

entry.title: Generalized Counters and Reversal Complexity
entry.summary: We generalize the definition of a counter and counter reversal complexity and investigate the power of generalized deterministic counter automata in terms of language recognition.
entry.arxiv:comment: 9 pages, no figures; Layout and content changed to some extent; Conference version
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: pp.318-326, Proceedings of TAMC 2006, Beijing, China, Springer LNCS, 3959

entry.title: Basic properties for sand automata
entry.summary: We prove several results about the relations between injectivity and surjectivity for sand automata. Moreover, we begin the exploration of the dynamical behavior of sand automata proving that the property of nilpotency is undecidable. We believe that the proof technique used for this last result might reveal useful for many other results in this context.

entry.title: On Invariance and Convergence in Time Complexity theory
entry.summary: This article introduces three invariance principles under which P is different from NP. In the second part a theorem of convergence is proven. This theorem states that for any language L there exists an infinite sequence of languages from O(n) that converges to L.

entry.title: A Note on Bulk Quantum Turing Machine
entry.summary: Recently, among experiments for realization of quantum computers, NMR quantum computers have achieved the most impressive succession. There is a model of the NMR quantum computation,namely Atsumi and Nishino's bulk quantum Turing Machine. It assumes, however, an unnatural assumption with quantum mechanics. We, then, define a more natural and quantum mechanically realizable modified bulk quantum Turing Machine, and show its computational ability by comparing complexity classes with quantum Turing Machine's counter part.

entry.title: On The Liniar Time Complexity of Finite Languages
entry.summary: The present paper presents and proves a proposition concerning the time complexity of finite languages. It is shown herein, that for any finite language (a language for which the set of words composing it is finite) there is a Turing machine that computes the language in such a way that for any input of length k the machine stops in, at most, k + 1 steps.

entry.title: On the Complexity of Real Functions
entry.summary: We develop a notion of computability and complexity of functions over the reals, which seems to be very natural when one tries to determine just how "difficult" a certain function is. This notion can be viewed as an extension of both BSS computability [Blum, Cucker, Shub, Smale 1998], and bit computability in the tradition of computable analysis [Weihrauch 2000] as it relies on the latter but allows some discontinuities and multiple values.

entry.title: Comment on "Some non-conventional ideas about algorithmic complexity"
entry.summary: We comment on a recent paper by D'Abramo [Chaos, Solitons & Fractals, 25 (2005) 29], focusing on the author's statement that an algorithm can produce a list of strings containing at least one string whose algorithmic complexity is greater than that of the entire list. We show that this statement, although perplexing, is not as paradoxical as it seems when the definition of algorithmic complexity is applied correctly.

entry.title: Time, Space, and Energy in Reversible Computing
entry.summary: We survey results of a quarter century of work on computation by reversible general-purpose computers (in this setting Turing machines), and general reversible simulation of irreversible computations, with respect to energy-, time- and space requirements.

author.name: Paul Vitanyi
author.arxiv:affiliation: CWI, University of Amsterdam, and National ICT Australia

entry.arxiv:comment: LaTeX, 10 pages, Proc. 2005 ACM International Conference on Computing Frontiers, Ischia, Italy, 4-6 May 2005 (1st Intn'l Workshop on Reversible Computing)

entry.title: On the Solution of Graph Isomorphism by Dynamical Algorithms
entry.summary: In the recent years, several polynomial algorithms of a dynamical nature have been proposed to address the graph isomorphism problem. In this paper we propose a generalization of an approach exposed in cond-mat/0209112 and find that this dynamical algorithm is covered by a combinatorial approach. It is possible to infer that polynomial dynamical algorithms addressing graph isomorphism are covered by suitable polynomial combinatorial approaches and thus are tackled by the same weaknesses as the last ones.

entry.title: Application of Kolmogorov complexity and universal codes to identity testing and nonparametric testing of serial independence for time series
entry.summary: We show that Kolmogorov complexity and such its estimators as universal codes (or data compression methods) can be applied for hypotheses testing in a framework of classical mathematical statistics. The methods for identity testing and nonparametric testing of serial independence for time series are suggested.

entry.title: Three lines proof of the lower bound for the matrix rigidity
entry.summary: The rigidity of a matrix describes the minimal number of entries one has to change to reduce matrix's rank to r. We give very simple combinatorial proof of the lower bound for the rigidity of Sylvester (special case of Hadamard) matrix that matches the best known result by de Wolf(2005) for Hadamard matrices proved by quantum information theoretical arguments.

entry.title: Finite automata for testing uniqueness of Eulerian trails
entry.summary: We investigate the condition under which the Eulerian trail of a digraph is unique, and design a finite automaton to examine it. The algorithm is effective, for if the condition is violated, it will be noticed immediately without the need to trace through the whole trail.

entry.title: A new sibling of BQP
entry.summary: We present a new quantum complexity class, called MQ^2, which is contained in AWPP. This class has a compact and simple mathematical definition, involving only polynomial-time computable functions and a unitarity condition. It contains both Deutsch-Jozsa's and Shor's algorithm, while its relation to BQP is unknown. This shows that in the complexity class hierarchy, BQP is not an extraordinary isolated island, but has ''siblings'' which as well can solve prime-factorization.

entry.title: Computing over the Reals: Foundations for Scientific Computing
entry.summary: We give a detailed treatment of the ``bit-model'' of computability and complexity of real functions and subsets of R^n, and argue that this is a good way to formalize many problems of scientific computation. In the introduction we also discuss the alternative Blum-Shub-Smale model. In the final section we discuss the issue of whether physical systems could defeat the Church-Turing Thesis.

entry.title: Online Learning and Resource-Bounded Dimension: Winnow Yields New Lower Bounds for Hard Sets
entry.summary: We establish a relationship between the online mistake-bound model of learning and resource-bounded dimension. This connection is combined with the Winnow algorithm to obtain new results about the density of hard sets under adaptive reductions. This improves previous work of Fu (1995) and Lutz and Zhao (2000), and solves one of Lutz and Mayordomo's "Twelve Problems in Resource-Bounded Measure" (1999).

entry.title: Comments on Beckmann's Uniform Reducts
entry.summary: Arnold Beckmann defined the uniform reduct of a propositional proof system f to be the set of those bounded arithmetical formulas whose propositional translations have polynomial size f-proofs. We prove that the uniform reduct of f + Extended Frege consists of all true bounded arithmetical formulas iff f + Extended Frege simulates every proof system.

entry.title: Towards Analog Reverse Time Computation
entry.summary: We report the consequences of a destabilization process on a simulated General Purpose Analog Computer. This new technology overcomes problems linked with serial ambiguity, and provides an analog bias to encode algorithms whose complexity is over polynomial. We also implicitly demonstrate how countermesures of the Stochastic Aperture Degeneracy could efficiently reach higher computational classes, and would open a road towards Analog Reverse Time Computation.

entry.title: Efficient algorithms for deciding the type of growth of products of integer matrices
entry.summary: For a given finite set $\Sigma$ of matrices with nonnegative integer entries we study the growth of $$ \max_t(\Sigma) = \max\{\|A_{1}... A_{t}\|: A_i \in \Sigma\}.$$ We show how to determine in polynomial time whether the growth with $t$ is bounded, polynomial, or exponential, and we characterize precisely all possible behaviors.

entry.title: Approximability of Bounded Occurrence Max Ones
entry.summary: We study the approximability of Max Ones when the number of variable occurrences is bounded by a constant. For conservative constraint languages (i.e., when the unary relations are included) we give a complete classification when the number of occurrences is three or more and a partial classification when the bound is two. For the non-conservative case we prove that it is either trivial or equivalent to the corresponding conservative problem under polynomial-time many-one reductions.

entry.title: On the structure of linear-time reducibility
entry.summary: In 1975, Ladner showed that under the hypothesis that P is not equal to NP, there exists a language which is neither in P, nor NP-complete. This result was latter generalized by Schoning and several authors to various polynomial-time complexity classes. We show here that such results also apply to linear-time reductions on RAMs (resp. Turing machines), and hence allow for separation results in linear-time classes similar to Ladner's ones for polynomial time.

entry.title: On symmetric sandpiles
entry.summary: A symmetric version of the well-known SPM model for sandpiles is introduced. We prove that the new model has fixed point dynamics. Although there might be several fixed points, a precise description of the fixed points is given. Moreover, we provide a simple closed formula for counting the number of fixed points originated by initial conditions made of a single column of grains.
entry.arxiv:comment: Will be presented at ACRI2006 conference

entry.title: Planar Graphs: Logical Complexity and Parallel Isomorphism Tests
entry.summary: We prove that every triconnected planar graph is definable by a first order sentence that uses at most 15 variables and has quantifier depth at most $11\log_2 n+43$. As a consequence, a canonic form of such graphs is computable in $AC^1$ by the 14-dimensional Weisfeiler-Lehman algorithm. This provides another way to show that the planar graph isomorphism is solvable in $AC^1$.

entry.title: A new function algebra of EXPTIME functions by safe nested recursion
entry.summary: Bellantoni and Cook have given a function-algebra characterization of the polynomial-time computable functions via an unbounded recursion scheme which is called safe recursion. Inspired by their work, we characterize the exponential-time computable functions with the use of a safe variant of nested recursion.

entry.title: Entropy generation in a model of reversible computation
entry.summary: We present a model in which, due to the quantum nature of the signals controlling the implementation time of successive unitary computational steps, \emph{physical} irreversibility appears in the execution of a \emph{logically} reversible computation.

entry.title: The Importance of the Algorithmic Information Theory to Construct a Possible Example Where NP # P - II: An Irreducible Sentence
entry.summary: In this short communication it is discussed the relation between disentangled states and algorithmic information theory aiming to construct an irreducible sentence whose length increases in a non-polynomial way when the number of qubits increases.

entry.title: P is not equal to NP
entry.summary: This submission has been withdrawn at the request of the author.

entry.title: A Polynomial Time Algorithm for 3-SAT
entry.summary: Article describes a class of efficient algorithms for 3SAT and their generalizations on SAT.
entry.arxiv:comment: 9 pages. The version consolidates results and shares know-how

entry.title: The DFAs of Finitely Different Languages
entry.summary: Two languages are "finitely different" if their symmetric difference is finite. We consider the DFAs of finitely different regular languages and find major structural similarities. We proceed to consider the smallest DFAs that recognize a language finitely different from some given DFA. Such "f-minimal" DFAs are not unique, and this non-uniqueness is characterized. Finally, we offer a solution to the minimization problem of finding such f-minimal DFAs.

entry.title: Tree automata and separable sets of input variables
entry.summary: We consider the computational complexity of tree transducers, depending on their separable sets of input variables.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: J. FILOMAT, v. 15, 2001, University of Nis, 61-71 p., ISSN 0354-5180 (http://www.pmf.ni.ac.yu/sajt/publikacije/filomat_15.html)

entry.title: Essential Inputs and Minimal Tree Automata
entry.summary: We continue studying essential inputs of trees and automata. Strongly essential inputs of trees are introduced and studied. Various examples for application in Computer Science are shown.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, 1 figure, Sixth International Conference on Discrete Mathematics and Applications, 31.08-02.09.2001, Bansko
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Proc. of ICDMA, 31.08-02.09.2001, Bansko, v.6, 77-85 p

entry.title: Tree Automata and Essential Subtrees
entry.summary: We introduce essential subtrees for terms (trees) and tree automata . There are some results concerning independent sets of subtrees and separable sets for a tree and an automaton.
entry.arxiv:comment: 9 pages, 2 figures, Sixth International Conference on Discrete Mathematics and Applications, Bansko, 2001
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Proc. of ICDMA, 31.08-02.09.2001, Bansko, v.6, 51-60 p

entry.title: FPRAS for computing a lower bound for weighted matching polynomial of graphs
entry.summary: We give a fully polynomial randomized approximation scheme to compute a lower bound for the matching polynomial of any weighted graph at a positive argument. For the matching polynomial of complete bipartite graphs with bounded weights these lower bounds are asymptotically optimal.

entry.title: The Complexity of Simple Stochastic Games
entry.summary: In this paper we survey the computational time complexity of assorted simple stochastic game problems, and we give an overview of the best known algorithms associated with each problem.
entry.arxiv:comment: Hi, while reading through literature i noticed that it has not yet been proved that computing the value vector of simple stochastic games is a Problem in FNP. This is why i came up with a prove in this seminar work of mine

entry.title: Assisted Problem Solving and Decompositions of Finite Automata
entry.summary: A study of assisted problem solving formalized via decompositions of deterministic finite automata is initiated. The landscape of new types of decompositions of finite automata this study uncovered is presented. Languages with various degrees of decomposability between undecomposable and perfectly decomposable are shown to exist.

entry.title: Report on Generic Case Complexity
entry.summary: This article is a short introduction to generic case complexity, which is a recently developed way of measuring the difficulty of a computational problem while ignoring atypical behavior on a small set of inputs. Generic case complexity applies to both recursively solvable and recursively unsolvable problems.

entry.title: Small weakly universal Turing machines
entry.summary: We give small universal Turing machines with state-symbol pairs of (6, 2), (3, 3) and (2, 4). These machines are weakly universal, which means that they have an infinitely repeated word to the left of their input and another to the right. They simulate Rule 110 and are currently the smallest known weakly universal Turing machines.

entry.title: On P vs. NP, Geometric Complexity Theory, and the Flip I: a high level view
entry.summary: Geometric complexity theory (GCT) is an approach to the $P$ vs. $NP$ and related problems through algebraic geometry and representation theory. This article gives a high-level exposition of the basic plan of GCT based on the principle, called the flip, without assuming any background in algebraic geometry or representation theory.

entry.title: Liquid State Machines in Adbiatic Quantum Computers for General Computation
entry.summary: Major mistakes do not read

entry.title: A Polynomial Time Algorithm for Graph Isomorphism
entry.summary: We claimed that there is a polynomial algorithm to test if two graphs are isomorphic. But the algorithm is wrong. It only tests if the adjacency matrices of two graphs have the same eigenvalues. There is a counterexample of two non-isomorphic graphs with the same eigenvalues.

entry.title: Analysis and Counterexamples Regarding Yatsenko's Polynomial-Time Algorithm for Solving the Traveling Salesman Problem
entry.summary: Yatsenko gives a polynomial-time algorithm for solving the traveling salesman problem. We examine the correctness of the algorithm and its construction. We also comment on Yatsenko's evaluation of the algorithm.

entry.title: A Family of Counter Examples to an Approach to Graph Isomorphism
entry.summary: We give a family of counter examples showing that the two sequences of polytopes $\Phi_{n,n}$ and $\Psi_{n,n}$ are different. These polytopes were defined recently by S. Friedland in an attempt at a polynomial time algorithm for graph isomorphism.

entry.title: On the complexity of finding gapped motifs
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn by the corresponding author because the newest version is now published in Journal of Discrete Algorithms.
entry.arxiv:comment: Published in Journal of Discrete Algorithms

entry.title: Approximation Resistant Predicates From Pairwise Independence
entry.summary: We study the approximability of predicates on $k$ variables from a domain $[q]$, and give a new sufficient condition for such predicates to be approximation resistant under the Unique Games Conjecture. Specifically, we show that a predicate $P$ is approximation resistant if there exists a balanced pairwise independent distribution over $[q]^k$ whose support is contained in the set of satisfying assignments to $P$.

entry.title: Separating NOF communication complexity classes RP and NP
entry.summary: We provide a non-explicit separation of the number-on-forehead communication complexity classes RP and NP when the number of players is up to \delta log(n) for any \delta<1. Recent lower bounds on Set-Disjointness [LS08,CA08] provide an explicit separation between these classes when the number of players is only up to o(loglog(n)).

entry.title: Adversary lower bounds for nonadaptive quantum algorithms
entry.summary: We present general methods for proving lower bounds on the query complexity of nonadaptive quantum algorithms. Our results are based on the adversary method of Ambainis.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Dans proceedings of WoLLIC 2008 - WoLLIC 2008 15th Workshop on Logic, Language, Information and Computation, Edinburgh : Royaume-Uni

entry.title: On NFAs Where All States are Final, Initial, or Both
entry.summary: We examine questions involving nondeterministic finite automata where all states are final, initial, or both initial and final. First, we prove hardness results for the nonuniversality and inequivalence problems for these NFAs. Next, we characterize the languages accepted. Finally, we discuss some state complexity problems involving such automata.

entry.title: Improved Monotone Circuit Depth Upper Bound for Directed Graph Reachability
entry.summary: We prove that the directed graph reachability problem (transitive closure) can be solved by monotone fan-in 2 boolean circuits of depth (1/2+o(1))(log n)^2, where n is the number of nodes. This improves the previous known upper bound (1+o(1))(log n)^2. The proof is non-constructive, but we give a constructive proof of the upper bound (7/8+o(1))(log n)^2.

entry.title: Complexity Classes as Mathematical Axioms
entry.summary: Treating a conjecture, P^#P != NP, on the separation of complexity classes as an axiom, an implication is found in three manifold topology with little obvious connection to complexity theory. This is reminiscent of Harvey Friedman's work on finitistic interpretations of large cardinal axioms.
entry.arxiv:comment: Some minor changes and one more reference. To appear in Ann. Math

entry.title: Modular difference logic is hard
entry.summary: In connection with machine arithmetic, we are interested in systems of constraints of the form x + k \leq y + k'. Over integers, the satisfiability problem for such systems is polynomial time. The problem becomes NP complete if we restrict attention to the residues for a fixed modulus N.

entry.title: Applying Practice to Theory
entry.summary: How can complexity theory and algorithms benefit from practical advances in computing? We give a short overview of some prior work using practical computing to attack problems in computational complexity and algorithms, informally describe how linear program solvers may be used to help prove new lower bounds for satisfiability, and suggest a research program for developing new understanding in circuit complexity.
entry.arxiv:comment: 16 pages, 1 figure; ACM SIGACT News, December 2008

entry.title: Extractors and an efficient variant of Muchnik's theorem
entry.summary: Muchnik's theorem about simple conditional descriprion states that for all words $a$ and $b$ there exists a short program $p$ transforming $a$ to $b$ that has the least possible length and is simple conditional on $b$. This paper presents a new proof of this theorem, based on extractors. Employing the extractor technique, two new versions of Muchnik's theorem for space- and time-bounded Kolmogorov complexity are proven.

entry.title: Unary finite automata vs. arithmetic progressions
entry.summary: We point out a subtle error in the proof of Chrobak's theorem that every unary NFA can be represented as a union of arithmetic progressions that is at most quadratically large. We propose a correction for this and show how Martinez's polynomial time algorithm, which realizes Chrobak's theorem, can be made correct accordingly. We also show that Martinez's algorithm cannot be improved to have logarithmic space, unless L = NL.

entry.title: A Factor 3/2 Approximation for Generalized Steiner Tree Problem with Distances One and Two
entry.summary: We design a 3/2 approximation algorithm for the Generalized Steiner Tree problem (GST) in metrics with distances 1 and 2. This is the first polynomial time approximation algorithm for a wide class of non-geometric metric GST instances with approximation factor below 2.

entry.title: Two-message quantum interactive proofs are in PSPACE
entry.summary: We prove that QIP(2), the class of problems having two-message quantum interactive proof systems, is a subset of PSPACE. This relationship is obtained by means of an efficient parallel algorithm, based on the multiplicative weights update method, for approximately solving a certain class of semidefinite programs.

entry.title: A General Notion of Useful Information
entry.summary: In this paper we introduce a general framework for defining the depth of a sequence with respect to a class of observers. We show that our general framework captures all depth notions introduced in complexity theory so far. We review most such notions, show how they are particular cases of our general depth framework, and review some classical results about the different depth notions.

entry.title: Some Considerations on Universality
entry.summary: The paper puts into discussion the concept of universality, in particular for structures not of the power of Turing computability. The question arises if for such structures a universal structure of the same kind exists or not. For that the construction of universal Turing machines and those with some constraints are presented in some detail.

entry.title: Intrinsically Universal Cellular Automata
entry.summary: This talk advocates intrinsic universality as a notion to identify simple cellular automata with complex computational behavior. After an historical introduction and proper definitions of intrinsic universality, which is discussed with respect to Turing and circuit universality, we discuss construction methods for small intrinsically universal cellular automata before discussing techniques for proving non universality.

entry.title: Small Turing universal signal machines
entry.summary: This article aims at providing signal machines as small as possible able to perform any computation (in the classical understanding). After presenting signal machines, it is shown how to get universal ones from Turing machines, cellular-automata and cyclic tag systems. Finally a halting universal signal machine with 13 meta-signals and 21 collision rules is presented.

entry.title: Computational Processes and Incompleteness
entry.summary: We introduce a formal definition of Wolfram's notion of computational process based on cellular automata, a physics-like model of computation. There is a natural classification of these processes into decidable, intermediate and complete. It is shown that in the context of standard finite injury priority arguments one cannot establish the existence of an intermediate computational process.

entry.title: Self-Assembly of Infinite Structures
entry.summary: We review some recent results related to the self-assembly of infinite structures in the Tile Assembly Model. These results include impossibility results, as well as novel tile assembly systems in which shapes and patterns that represent various notions of computation self-assemble. Several open questions are also presented and motivated.

entry.title: On the boundaries of solvability and unsolvability in tag systems. Theoretical and Experimental Results
entry.summary: Several older and more recent results on the boundaries of solvability and unsolvability in tag systems are surveyed. Emphasis will be put on the significance of computer experiments in research on very small tag systems.

entry.title: Response to Refutation of Aslam's Proof that NP = P
entry.summary: This paper provides a further refinement to the previous response by introducing new structures and algorithms for counting VMPs of common \emph{Edge Requirement} (ER) and hence for counting the perfect matchings.
entry.arxiv:comment: Total 9 pages, including the figures. Have further minimized the overlap, with only references to the main paper

entry.title: A Survey on Continuous Time Computations
entry.summary: We provide an overview of theories of continuous time computation. These theories allow us to understand both the hardness of questions related to continuous time dynamical systems and the computational power of continuous time analog models. We survey the existing models, summarizing results, and point to relevant references in the literature.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: New Computational Paradigms. Changing Conceptions of What is Computable. (Cooper, S.B. and L{\"o}we, B. and Sorbi, A., Eds.). New York, Springer-Verlag, pages 383-423. 2008

entry.title: The Complexity of Iterated Strategy Elimination
entry.summary: We consider the computational complexity of the question whether a certain strategy can be removed from a game by means of iterated elimination of dominated strategies.
